positive.review:
Ok before you buy.
I give this a 9/10 but that's my opinion.

1st and foremost this IS an idle game, yes you can code to automate it, but you will leave this game running for hours to gather resources.

Will it teach you python coding? very basic only.

is it fun - yes if you enjoy puzzles / coding and don't mind the idle waiting for resources.

I give this a 9/10, I'm loving this, it's a slow process, I'm not a programmer. The game does teach you most of what you need to know, and so far I've been able to work out the rest myself. But it's very rewarding when you do work out how to complete the more complex tasks.

That said I feel there is a few QoL features missing. like an ingame console for debugging rather than using a .txt doc, and the lack of a search function in the ingame documentation, the documentation is very basic.

If you have an interest in coding, even if you have no experience then this game may be for you.

It's cheap, give it a go.

TLDR: Good game for simple programming techniques and beginners - but still has a way to go for more advanced learners.

I want to just say that I do enjoy the game a lot and think its really well made so far, I just like ranting. I also understand the game is still in an earlish development stage.

Good Points:
- Teaches "simple" programming techniques
- Actually fun to play

Things I wish that were changed:
- Gameplay: Gameplay is SUPER fun near the start, drops off near the middle around bones/maze, then just gets kinda boring. Obviously as an afk farm game this will happen 90% of the time, but even then I felt like the scaling was off on certain upgrades / gather rates.
- Bad Programming: The game does not enforce GOOD programming techniques and instead will typically reward doing things that realistically worse than optimal solution. For example, maze search algorithm seems to work faster by using DFS algorithms compared to A* / heuristic based searches (likely because the max size is 32x32 and A* is usually slower in this case, so possible increase the scale of farm more near end game). Maybe what I have been implementing is wrong as well, but I see solutions that have people just spam 20 drones into the maze and randomly move around which is just dumb. Limiting drones to 1 per maze would be a good change imo.
- Drone Memory: No shared memory between drones. Obviously for beginners dealing with locks/parallel code may get really confusing, but I wish there was at least an option to have it. This feature makes it pretty much impossible to write GOOD code and instead reinforces bad manual patterns and typically requires rewriting code to be dumber than what it was before just to be faster.
- Code Editing: Enable editing code whilst it is also running. I didn't opt to using an external IDE but allowing for code to run whilst also editing would be great as it was annoying to copy/paste into a new box to allow for the current code to run.


New feature Ideas:
- Multifarm/world: Allow for multiple words/farms to run at once. Would be a nice unlock near the end. Not necessarily needed as you could just subdivide the current farm and set each drone to a quadrant but I think would be nice for different farms.
- World Types: Once you finish all the farm upgrades, go to a new world with even harder stuff. E.g. now you mine minerals etc, then goes to space etc. (just some ideas)
- Complexity: Create more complex types of plants with different interactions to learn more complex datatypes (e.g. heaps, trees etc.), I think changing how the tree works should spawn an actual tree like datatype you can traverse to harvest at leaf nodes. This would make it a great beginner to search algorithms before the maze as I think the maze part is a large leap for some beginners. You could even expand this for different tree types for different algorithms.
- Multi-language Support: Implement multi-language support.
This game was fun to play and the gameplay itself was very creative. Never played a game like this before but I enjoyed every bit.
Another fun programming-genre game. Definitely recommend. Progression feels very rewarding. The game has really nice documentation as well
The version I played (pre-1.0) didn't have too much to do, but, overall, it was a couple of hours of geeky fun.

Once upon a time I was a developer, so I was already familiar with writing code, functions, recursion, etc., Farmer Was Replaced has still been a great puzzle game. The methods of optimizing planting and harvesting of different crop types provide a satisfying challenge, forcing you to rethink your approach. Almost everything can be brute forced, but it's enjoyable to figure out the fastest way to collect your crops, from megapumpkins to vast fields of size sorted cacti. TLDR: This game is amazing at making you problem-solve, which is what games and code are fundamentally about. It's also very well put together and has a nice, chill atmosphere. 10/10

I love incremental games, but realistically it's a pretty stale genre. Nowadays, most of them advertise some vague unique selling point that ends up being a minor thing—if not an afterthought—after an hour of play, and then it's either a Cookie Clicker or an Adventure Capitalist with a different theme and maybe more content to grind through.

The Farmer Was Replaced is something completely different!

Obviously the coding aspect is very novel. I've always been interested in code but never had a good excuse to indulge in my free time. Well, this game was the perfect excuse! And the coding mechanic fits the incremental genre so perfectly. 

In a typical incremental game, you'd usually be juggling different options, prioritizing one upgrade or another, in an effort to optimize your resource acquisition. But that always feels somewhat arbitrary, reliant on the whims of the developer and how they balanced the values of an upgrade. Here, to maximize your resource acquisition, you're instead trying to optimize movement logic, automate decision-making, and solve programming problems (again, in the most optimal way possible). It all feels so natural; I'm surprised no one had done it before.

And then, the game doesn't take this strong foundation for granted and introduces interesting progression elements that will periodically encourage you to revisit code you've written before to improve its logic. You'll increase the field's size, making you realize you need to write your code to be adaptive to it. Once the grid is big enough, you'll realize you're wasting a lot of time going places, and now you're implementing edge warping logic to your movement behavior. And once you unlock extra drones, then... you might have to revisit a lot of your code like I did. But that's part of what makes this game so great.

It isn't a pure programming game. It's an idle-like game where you use programming to do stuff. You have to grind and wait to unlock language constructs.

- The language is pretty much Python.
- You start only with the bare minimum and have to unlock everything else, loop statements, comparators, variables, etc.
- The UI is awful on 1080p. Text is too big and while you can scale it the resource indicators will pretty much disappear while text is still filling up the entire screen. I can't imagine playing this on a laptop.

I don't get the target audience of this game. If you already know how to code it is boring [i](the early game at least)[/i]. If you want to learn it's not user friendly and you would be much better playing with PyCharm and the thousand of learning resources which are better and available for FREE.

This is, hands down, the best Python tutorial I've ever seen. Perhaps even the best programming tutorial in general. It applies the good ol' teaching rule that's common in game design: give people mechanics piecemeal, and slowly ramp up the complexity, pushing them to use more mechanics. In this case, mechanics being the elements of the language - loops, variables, functions. Such a great idea.

So why the negative review, then? Let's put it like this. If you're looking to learn coding, this review won't be of much value to you. If you already know your way around the Arcane Tongues and like using them to solve more theoretical problems - math problems, algorithm design and so on - same thing. So if you fall into these categories, I actually recommend the game wholeheartedly. It's made for you.

Me, however... I am an experienced, professional Arcanist, who's dabbled in many different branches of the Arts. Not much in Python, so I thought, hey, this might be a nice way to practice my chops. Right?

Sadly, I see coding as merely a means to an end. I like it, I like engineering a good solution, I love it when your code that you spent the last 5 hours writing just works on the first try. But still, I code because I want to affect reality. I like building stuff. Coding is just an aspect of it.

And this game really is just coding. And designing your algorithm. Your reward? Number go up - and that's fine, it's an idle game. But somehow in this case it feels pointless, and I have no idea why.

You're writing code to write more code. I can only speak for myself, but in my experience the goal is to write [i]less[/i] code. That's why we use libraries, that's why we write reusable functions, and this is why those of us of lesser Aracane affinity began summoning the fickle, unreliable demons to do their work for them: Vibe Wizards, we call them. Still, we share a goal.

To summarise: As a coding tutorial? This is absolute peak. As a "coding for the sake of coding" challenge? You betcha. As an idle game? Eeeeh. Nah.

And if you're one of the Ancients who once tasted the intoxicating ambrosia that is Colobot and has been looking for another sip for the past decade... move along, brother. This ain't it. 

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42922988/]Curator page[/url]

In the reviews, I've seen many people recommend the game as an easy way to learn programming. I think this is true if you have very basic skills and struggle even to understand loops and functions. If you studied programming in school or university, I highly doubt you'll learn anything new. I think you'll be much more successful in programming if, for example, you try writing some scripts to help you with your work (to cope w/ Excel slavery).

For me, the game lacks interesting challenges, unless you're thrilled by the thought of harvesting 10 million wheat per second, unlocking all the achievements, and all of the research tree.
I was also confused by the leveling tree, which initially doesn't even allow you to use "if" functions or logical operators (to be fair, you can unlock them very early in the game).

Although maybe I am simply not the target audience: if you are an absolute beginner or, on the contrary, a professional Python developer, you may like it.

This is, hands down, the best Python tutorial I've ever seen. Perhaps even the best programming tutorial in general. It applies the good ol' teaching rule that's common in game design: give people mechanics piecemeal, and slowly ramp up the complexity, pushing them to use more mechanics. In this case, mechanics being the elements of the language - loops, variables, functions. Such a great idea.

So why the negative review, then? Let's put it like this. If you're looking to learn coding, this review won't be of much value to you. If you already know your way around the Arcane Tongues and like using them to solve more theoretical problems - math problems, algorithm design and so on - same thing. So if you fall into these categories, I actually recommend the game wholeheartedly. It's made for you.

Me, however... I am an experienced, professional Arcanist, who's dabbled in many different branches of the Arts. Not much in Python, so I thought, hey, this might be a nice way to practice my chops. Right?

Sadly, I see coding as merely a means to an end. I like it, I like engineering a good solution, I love it when your code that you spent the last 5 hours writing just works on the first try. But still, I code because I want to affect reality. I like building stuff. Coding is just an aspect of it.

And this game really is just coding. And designing your algorithm. Your reward? Number go up - and that's fine, it's an idle game. But somehow in this case it feels pointless, and I have no idea why.

You're writing code to write more code. I can only speak for myself, but in my experience the goal is to write [i]less[/i] code. That's why we use libraries, that's why we write reusable functions, and this is why those of us of lesser Aracane affinity began summoning the fickle, unreliable demons to do their work for them: Vibe Wizards, we call them. Still, we share a goal.

To summarise: As a coding tutorial? This is absolute peak. As a "coding for the sake of coding" challenge? You betcha. As an idle game? Eeeeh. Nah.

And if you're one of the Ancients who once tasted the intoxicating ambrosia that is Colobot and has been looking for another sip for the past decade... move along, brother. This ain't it.
